items.title: Chile Creates Giant Lithium Company: Codelco-SQM Partnership Gives State Control
items.summary: Chile's state-owned Codelco and private miner SQM announced the creation of Nova Andino Litio SpA to exploit lithium in the Atacama Desert until 2060. The Chilean state will receive around 70% of operating margin (2025-2030) and 85% starting in 2031, giving government control of one of the world's richest lithium reserves.
items.raw_content: State-owned Codelco and private miner SQM form partnership controlling Chilean lithium. New company will carry out exploration, extraction, production and commercialization until 2060. Chile has 40% of world's lithium reserves and is second-largest producer globally.

items.title: Honduras Electoral Crisis: 8 Latin American Nations Reject Castro's Recount Decree
items.summary: Argentina, Bolivia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Guatemala, Paraguay, Peru, and Dominican Republic rejected President Xiomara Castro's decree ordering general vote recount in Honduras. With 97% counted, Nasry Asfura leads with 40.5% vs. Salvador Nasralla's 39.1%. Castro declared elections 'null'. Asfura expected to be sworn in January 27 for 2026-2030 term.
items.raw_content: Major political crisis in Honduras as president rejects election results. Eight neighboring countries recognize opposition candidate. Violence against opposition members reported. Separation of only 40,000 votes between top two candidates.

items.title: FAO Food Price Index Falls in December 2025, Down Year-Over-Year
items.summary: FAO Food Price Index averaged 124.3 points in December, down 0.6% from November and 2.3% from year ago. Indicates declining global food prices with implications for Latin American agricultural exporters.
items.raw_content: Global food price index shows continued decline. Impacts Latin American agricultural economies including Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay as major exporters.

items.title: Trump's Venezuela Oil Boom Requires Stability That's Now Lacking
items.summary: Following Maduro's capture, Trump administration organizing meetings with US oil executives to rebuild Venezuela's energy infrastructure. However, experts warn rebuilding will take decade and require hundreds of billions in investment. Current production at 934,000 bpd vs 3 million in 1990s.
items.raw_content: Venezuela disruptions may briefly lift oil prices but supply glut keeps prices low. Realistic estimates put marginal extra production at 250-300k bpd versus expected global demand growth of 750k-1.25mbd. Post-Maduro era likely messier and more protracted than hoped.

items.title: Brazil AI Digital Infrastructure: 2025 Turning Point, 2026 Global AI Map Entry
items.summary: Brazil positioned to enter global AI map in 2026 following 2025 digital infrastructure breakthroughs. Region sees AI adoption acceleration with 77% of Latin Americans already using AI regularly.
items.raw_content: Brazil AI development accelerating. Mexico launched largest public AI school in Latin America. Brazil ranks 9th globally for AI trust and acceptance. Costa Rica 7th for regular AI use. Argentina 11th for AI knowledge.

items.title: Mexico Imposes 35% Tariffs on China to Curb 'Back Door' to US Market
items.summary: Mexico imposed sweeping tariffs up to 35% on goods from China and other Asian countries without free trade deals, effective beginning of year. Includes 1,400 products: textiles, plastics, steel, aluminum, paper. Indicates increased scrutiny of nearshoring strategies using Mexico as indirect route to US.
items.raw_content: Mexico tariffs announced December 11, took effect January 2026. Mexican regulators finally reacting to pressure to harmonize trade rules with North American region. FDI increased 8.2% in Q1 2025, reaching $40.9B by Q3 (15% YoY rise). Manufacturing captured 37% of investment.

items.title: EU-Mercosur Deal Opens Tech Trade Door
items.summary: EU-Mercosur trade agreement opening technology trade opportunities including AI, mobile broadband, and digital services between Europe and South American bloc (Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay, Paraguay).
items.raw_content: Historic trade deal between EU and Mercosur includes technology sector provisions. Covers artificial intelligence, mobile broadband, digital infrastructure. Represents major market access for both regions.

items.title: Australia Backs Rare Earth Projects in Brazil with $100M Financing
items.summary: Export Finance Australia signaling potential financing up to US$100 million for two rare earth projects in Brazil. Indicates growing international interest in Latin American critical minerals amid supply chain diversification efforts.
items.raw_content: Australian government-backed financing for Brazilian rare earth projects. Part of global effort to diversify critical mineral supply chains away from China dominance. Brazil positioning as alternative rare earth supplier.

items.title: Brazil Iron Ore Exports Expected to Remain Strong in 2026 After Record 2025
items.summary: Brazil exported 416.4 million tonnes of iron ore in 2025, largest export volume ever recorded. Strong export outlook continues for 2026 driven by global steel demand and infrastructure investment.
items.raw_content: Brazil sets new iron ore export record in 2025. Projections show continued strong demand in 2026. Main customers include China, Europe, and other major steel producing nations.

items.title: Ecuador Reopens Mining Cadastre to Medium/Large-Scale Projects in Q1 2026
items.summary: Ecuador's medium and large-scale mining cadastre expected to reopen in Q1 2026 after closure in 2018 amid irregularity concerns. Attracts most foreign investment and signals Ecuador's renewed openness to mining sector.
items.raw_content: Mining registry closed since 2018 due to irregularities. Reopening signals pro-mining policy shift. Expected to attract significant foreign investment in copper, gold sectors. Infrastructure improvements underway.

items.title: Colombia Renewables Miss Two-Thirds of 2026 Target, Power Shortage Risk
items.summary: Colombia unlikely to meet 2026 target of 6 GW renewable capacity, having added only 2 GW of 6 GW goal. Consultants warn power system increasingly vulnerable and urgent market reforms needed to avert energy crunch by 2027.
items.raw_content: Colombia added only 2,000 MW of clean generation vs 6,000 MW target. Project execution effectively paralyzed. Risk of supply shortfalls by 2027 tangible. Clean energy investment fell 70% to $410M in 2023. High capital costs and policy changes blamed.

items.title: ElectroHuila Opens Colombia's First Public Utility Solar Farm Built in 79 Days
items.summary: ElectroHuila finished and inaugurated first solar farm by Colombian public energy company in just 79 days. El Bote plant has 990 kW installed capacity and 1,620 solar panels. Demonstrates rapid deployment potential despite sector challenges.
items.raw_content: First solar plant built by public energy company in Colombia. Rapid 79-day construction timeline. 990 kW capacity. Model for public sector renewable energy development.

items.title: Peru Mining Faces 2026 Amid Uncertainty and New Momentum
items.summary: Peru's mining sector enters 2026 marked by internal tensions and election process. Operational risks include illegal mining and slow administrative procedures. However, major projects like Tia Maria and Southern Copper expansions moving forward.
items.raw_content: Southern Copper aims to increase production from 987,000 tons to 1.81 million tons by 2026. $10.3 billion earmarked for Peru projects. Tia Maria considered most visible new mining investment. Political uncertainty remains major risk.

items.title: Paraguay Soybean Imports to Brazil Surge 472% Amid Price Dynamics
items.summary: Brazil increased Paraguay soybean imports by 472% from 176,100 tons to 1,007,000 tons (2023-2025). Despite being global soybean leader, Brazilian crushing plants source from Paraguay when imports arrive cheaper than domestic soybeans after freight/taxes.
items.raw_content: Dramatic shift in South American soybean trade patterns. Price dynamics drive Brazilian imports from neighbor. Logistics and cost factors enable Paraguayan competitiveness in Brazilian market. Paraguay production projected 10.5-11 million tons 2025-26.

items.title: OECD Lowers 2026 Growth Forecast for Argentina, Tweaks Inflation Estimate
items.summary: OECD cut Argentina 2026 recovery forecast to 4.3% GDP growth with higher inflation projections. Despite cuts, still projects robust recovery sustained by higher real disposable incomes and favorable financing conditions. Milei government facing pressure with bond declines and foreign reserve pressure.
items.raw_content: OECD revises Argentina outlook downward but still optimistic. 4.3% growth projected for 2026. Political fragility and financial tension combining. Stock market plummeting, dollars fleeing. Foreign-currency bond maturities exceed $8.4B in 2026 while net reserves only slightly positive.

items.title: Brazil Trade Surplus 2026 Projected Higher Than Government Forecasts
items.summary: Brazil expecting trade surplus between $70-90 billion in 2026. Posted $68.3B surplus in 2025 (down from $74.2B in 2024) as imports increased faster than exports. Strong commodity export performance continuing.
items.raw_content: Brazil trade surplus remains strong despite decline from 2024 peak. Import growth accelerating. Commodity exports remain backbone. 2026 projections optimistic based on iron ore, soybeans, oil.

items.title: Costa Rica 2026 Elections: 20 Candidates, Public Security Tops Concerns
items.summary: Costa Rica general elections scheduled February 1, 2026 with 20 presidential candidates. Laura Fernández (pro-government) holds slight edge, followed by Fabricio Alvarado (far-right evangelical). Public security tops voter concerns but 55% remain undecided in October polling.
items.raw_content: Over 3.7 million voters to elect president, two vice presidents, 57 legislative seats. Runoff April 5 if no candidate gets 40%. Leading candidates: Fernández (government continuity), Alvarado (conservative), Ramos (Liberación Nacional), Dobles (environmental advocate).

items.title: Guatemala 2026: Critical Year for Institutional Appointments and Justice
items.summary: 2026 pivotal year for Guatemala as four fundamental institutions renew mandates: Attorney General (Consuelo Porras term ends May), Supreme Electoral Tribunal (March), Constitutional Court. UN warns selection processes could lead to co-opted judicial system if not transparent.
items.raw_content: Critical appointments determine Guatemala's democratic trajectory. Current Attorney General presided over eight years of justice setbacks. TSE magistrates crucial for electoral integrity. International community urged to support transparency in selection processes.

items.title: Panama Canal Transit Rebound: 33 Daily Average Projected for 2026
items.summary: Panama Canal operational conditions stabilized by early 2026. Daily average transits projected at 33 in 2026 (below 36 capacity) due to US tariff policies affecting trade volumes. ACP reports $5.7B yearly revenue enabling infrastructure investments.
items.raw_content: Canal recovered to 13,404 transits by September 2025 end. Drought impacts subsiding but US tariff policies limiting full capacity utilization. Toll structure remains unchanged for 2026. Reservation system continues for transit planning.

items.title: CK Hutchison Panama Ports Deal: 2026 as Make-or-Break Year
items.summary: Hong Kong conglomerate CK Hutchison's $22.8 billion global ports sale hung in balance 10 months after announcement. Strategic exit devolved into high-stakes geopolitical stand-off between Washington and Beijing over control of global trade arteries near Panama Canal.
items.raw_content: Billionaire Li Ka-shing's ports sale caught in US-China geopolitical tensions. Panama Canal zone ports strategic for global trade. Washington concerned about Chinese control of critical infrastructure. Deal outcome impacts regional trade architecture.

items.title: Brazil Comprehensive Crypto Regulations Launch February 2026
items.summary: Brazil Central Bank introducing comprehensive cryptocurrency regulatory framework February 2026. Includes licensing requirements, enhanced AML/CFT rules, mandatory customer asset segregation. Non-compliant institutions must cease operations by November 2026.
items.raw_content: Major regulatory milestone for Latin American crypto sector. Brazil establishing clear licensing regime. AML/CFT compliance mandatory. Customer protection through asset segregation required. November 2026 compliance deadline.

items.title: Colombia Crypto Tax Reporting Begins 2026: OECD Framework Adoption
items.summary: Colombia's DIAN mandated crypto exchanges to report detailed user and transaction data starting 2026 tax year. First full reporting cycle for 2026 with submissions due May 2027. Adopting OECD's Crypto-Asset Reporting Framework for global tax cooperation.
items.raw_content: Colombia implementing international crypto tax standards. Exchanges must report user transactions. OECD CARF framework standardizes global reporting. Enhances tax compliance and transparency in crypto sector.

items.title: Latin America AI Adoption Leads Globally: 77% Regular Use
items.summary: 77% of Latin American consumers already regularly use AI technology, positioning region as global leader. Costa Rica ranks 7th globally for AI use, Brazil 9th for AI trust, Argentina 11th for AI knowledge. Industry demand driving adoption from ground up.
items.raw_content: Latin America demonstrates exceptional AI adoption rates exceeding global averages. WhatsApp (80% LatAm penetration) and contactless payments create foundation for invisible banking. Region becoming primary testing ground for AI-powered financial services.

items.title: Mexico Greenlights 20 Renewable Energy Plants: $4.75B Investment
items.summary: Private companies investing $4.75 billion to build 20 renewable energy projects across 11 Mexican states. Adding 3,320 MW generation capacity and 1,488 MW storage. 15 solar plants (2,471 MW) and 5 wind farms (849 MW).
items.raw_content: Major private sector renewable energy investment in Mexico. Diversified across solar and wind. Includes significant storage capacity for grid stability. Supports Mexico's energy transition goals and grid modernization.

items.title: Caribbean Tourism Rebounds After Brief Venezuela-Related Airspace Disruption
items.summary: Caribbean tourism fully resumed after brief early January 2026 airspace restrictions linked to Venezuela geopolitical developments. FAA directives affecting US operators ended quickly. Booking levels strong for early 2026, with summer 2026 interest up 15% YoY.
items.raw_content: Temporary airspace restrictions in early January 2026 due to Venezuela situation. Commercial airline service returned to standard schedules. Accommodations remain open with strong bookings. Caribbean Tourism Organization emphasizes safe, seamless visitor experiences.

items.title: Jamaica Tourism Recovery Delayed: 80% of Pre-Hurricane Levels Expected by End 2026
items.summary: Jamaica tourism recovery slower than expected following Hurricane Melissa (October 2025). Visitor arrivals projected to reach only 80% of pre-hurricane levels by end 2026. 70% of hotel inventory online by December 2025, 80% recovery by February 2026, near full capacity by late 2026.
items.raw_content: Hurricane Melissa in late October 2025 devastated Jamaica tourism infrastructure. Gradual recovery underway with phased hotel reopenings. Tourism crucial to Jamaican economy. Climate resilience becoming critical sector concern.

items.title: Bolivia Lithium Window Closing: Economic Crisis Threatens Development Plans
items.summary: Bolivia faces economic strain after 2025 election. Foreign exchange reserves depleted to $1.1B (down from $15B peak in 2014). Lithium export by 2026 looking completely unrealistic despite agreements with Russian and Chinese firms. Production stalling despite industrialization promises.
items.raw_content: Bolivia's 23 million tons lithium reserves remain largely untapped. Deals with CBC consortium and Rosatom/Uranium One face delays requiring legislative approval. American firms largely moved to countries with stable governance. Heading toward potential debt crisis.

items.title: Latin America Digital Service Adoption Accelerates Amid Regulatory Shifts
items.summary: Latin America accelerating digital service adoption across key sectors with evolving regulatory frameworks. Focus on cross-border data flows, consumer protection law updates, payment system interoperability. Brazil establishing AI Pilot Regulatory Sandbox.
items.raw_content: Regional regulatory roadmaps for 2026 emphasize digital transformation enablement. Brazil ANATEL consulting on ethical AI use in telecoms. Payment system interoperability advancing. Consumer protection frameworks modernizing for digital economy.
